item.gloss: Chiefest: 'At the head or top in importance; most important, influential', OEDO.
Dross: ‘Refuse; rubbish; worthless, impure matter’, OEDO.
Soujourner: 'One who sojourns; a temporary resident', OEDO.
Incomprehensible: ‘That cannot be contained or circumscribed within limits; illimitable, boundless, infinite; immense’, OEDO.
Temporal: ‘Secular as opposed to sacred’, OEDO.

Providence: ‘The foreknowing and protective care of God (or nature, etc.); divine direction, control, or guidance’, OEDO. On providence in early modern England see Alexandra Walsham, Providence in Early Modern England (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 1999).
Avouch: ‘To vouch to the certainty of, vouch for, guarantee’, OEDO.
Temporal: ‘Secular as opposed to sacred’, OEDO.
Posterity: 'The descendants collectively of any person (or, in extended use, any living thing); all who are descended from a common ancestor', OEDO.
Candid: ‘Pure, clear; stainless, innocent’, OEDO.
Sweeten: ‘To make less unpleasant or painful; to alleviate, lighten, mitigate’, OEDO.
Temporal: ‘Secular as opposed to sacred’, OEDO.
Check: ‘To hold in check or restraint; to curb, control; to act as a check on’, OEDO
Grief: ‘Mental pain, distress, or sorrow’, OEDO.
Grief: ‘Mental pain, distress, or sorrow’, OEDO.
Chiefest: ‘At the head or top in importance; most important, influential’, OEDO.
Vouchsafe: ‘To show a gracious readiness or willingness, to grant readily, to condescend or deign, to do something’, OEDO.
Temporal: ‘Secular as opposed to sacred’, OEDO.
Posterity: ‘The descendants collectively of any person (or, in extended use, any living thing); all who are descended from a common ancestor’, OEDO.

Jointure: 'A sole estate limited to the wife, being a competent livelihood of freehold for the wife of lands and tenements, to take effect upon the death of the husband for the life of the wife at least', OEDO. See Amy Louise Erickson, Women and Property in Early Modern England (London: Routledge, 1995), 25-6, 119-22.
Convulsion: ‘An involuntary contraction, stiffening, or ‘drawing up’ of a muscle, limb, etc.’, OEDO.

Salvation: ‘The saving of the soul; the deliverance from sin and its consequences, and admission to eternal bliss, wrought for man by the atonement of Christ’, OEDO. On Protestantism and salvation, see Alec Ryrie, Being Protestant in Reformation Britain (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2013), chap. 2.
Grief: ‘Hurt, harm, mischief or injury done or caused by another’, OEDO.
Extremity: 'Extreme or inordinate intensity or violence (of passion, action, suffering, labour, etc.)', OEDO.
Palsy: ‘Paralysis or paresis (weakness) of all or part of the body, sometimes with tremor’, OEDO.
Injure: ‘To do outrage to (a person) in speech; to speak injuriously to or of; to insult, revile, abuse, slander offensively’, OEDO.
Grief: ‘Hurt, harm, mischief or injury done or caused by another’, OEDO.
Signal: ‘Notable, conspicuous; remarkable, striking’, OEDO.
Palsy: ‘Paralysis or paresis (weakness) of all or part of the body, sometimes with tremor’, OEDO.
Apprehension: ‘Fear as to what may happen; dread’, OEDO.
Part: ‘A personal quality or attribute, esp. of an intellectual kind; an ability, gift, or talent. Usually in plural’, OEDO.
Article: ‘Each of the distinct heads or points of an agreement or treaty. Chiefly in plural: a set of these points comprising a formal agreement (frequently with of)’, OEDO.
Grief: ‘Hurt, harm, mischief or injury done or caused by another’, OEDO.
Bowels: ‘The interior or inside of the body’, OEDO.

Providence: 'The foreknowing and protective care of God (or nature, etc.); divine direction, control, or guidance', OEDO. On providence in early modern England see Alexandra Walsham, Providence in Early Modern England (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 1999).
Posterity: ‘The descendants collectively of any person (or, in extended use, any living thing); all who are descended from a common ancestor’, OEDO.
Grief: ‘Hurt, harm, mischief or injury done or caused by another’, OEDO.
Posterity: ‘The descendants collectively of any person (or, in extended use, any living thing); all who are descended from a common ancestor’, OEDO.
Country: ‘The land of a person's birth … in the narrower one of the particular district to which a person belongs’, OEDO.

Presbyterians: ‘Members of a church governed by elders or presbyters and minister in a hierarchy of representative courts. Their doctrine is fundamentally Calvinistic. The Church of Scotland became presbyterian after the Reformation’, Dictionary of Christianity, ed. J. C. Cooper (Abingdon: Routledge, 2013), 219-20. On presbyterianism in the seventeenth century, see Chad van Dixhoorn, 'The Seventeenth Century and the Westminster Assembly', in The Oxford Handbook of Presbyterianism, ed. Gary Scott Smith and P. C. Kemeny (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2019), 29-49.
Grief: ‘Mental pain, distress, or sorrow’, OEDO.

Providence: 'The foreknowing and protective care of God (or nature, etc.); divine direction, control, or guidance', OEDO. On providence in early modern England see Alexandra Walsham, Providence in Early Modern England (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 1999).
Country: ‘An area of land of defined extent characterized by its human occupants or boundaries; a district or administrative region, typically one smaller than a nation or state’, OEDO.
Sweet: ‘Having pleasant disposition and manners’, OEDO.
Society: ‘Companionship, fellowship, or company’, OEDO.
Assignment: 'Appointment to office, nomination, designation; setting apart for a purpose’, OEDO.
Temporal: ‘Secular as opposed to sacred’, OEDO.

Entail: ‘The settlement of the succession of a landed estate, so that it cannot be bequeathed at pleasure by any one possessor; the rule of descent settled for any estate; the fixed or prescribed line of devolution’, OEDO.
Country: ‘The land of a person's birth … in the narrower one of the particular district to which a person belongs’, OEDO.
Guardian: ‘A person who has, or is by law entitled to, the custody of the person or property (or both) of an infant or other person legally incapable of managing his or her own affairs’, OEDO.

Providence: ‘The foreknowing and protective care of God (or nature, etc.); divine direction, control, or guidance, OEDO. On providence in early modern England see Alexandra Walsham, Providence in Early Modern England (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 1999).
Surprisal: ‘The act of surprising or state of being surprised; something that surprises’, OEDO.

Providence: ‘The foreknowing and protective care of God (or nature, etc.); divine direction, control, or guidance’, OEDO. On providence in early modern England see Alexandra Walsham, Providence in Early Modern England (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 1999).
Immergent: ‘Unexpectedly arising, urgent', OEDO.
Tabled: ‘To provide (a guest or customer) with food or hospitality at table; to provide with daily meals’, OEDO.

Providence: ‘The foreknowing and protective care of God (or nature, etc.); divine direction, control, or guidance’, OEDO. On providence in early modern England see Alexandra Walsham, Providence in Early Modern England (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 1999).
Heat: ‘The intense or violent stage of any action; greatest vehemence or intensity; height, stress’, OEDO.
Schismatic: ‘One who promotes or countenances schism or breach of external unity in the Church’, OEDO.

Presbyterians: ‘Members of a church governed by elders or presbyters and minister in a hierarchy of representative courts. Their doctrine is fundamentally Calvinistic. The Church of Scotland became presbyterian after the Reformation’, Dictionary of Christianity, ed. J. C. Cooper (Abingdon: Routledge, 2013), 219-20. On presbyterianism in the seventeenth century, see Chad van Dixhoorn, ‘The Seventeenth Century and the Westminster Assembly’, in The Oxford Handbook of Presbyterianism, ed. Gary Scott Smith and P. C. Kemeny (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2019), 29-49.
Papist: ‘Derogatory term for a Roman Catholic’, OEDO.
Sweet: ‘Gentle, easy,’ OEDO.
Bottoming: ’The action of setting something on a sure basis or foundation', OEDO.
Green: ‘Immature, raw, untrained, inexperienced’, OEDO.
Grief: ‘Mental pain, distress, or sorrow’, OEDO.
Vitals: ‘Those parts or organs of the body, esp. the human body, essential to life’, OEDO.
Consumption: ‘Abnormality or loss of humours, resulting in wasting (extreme weight loss) of the body; such wasting’, OEDO.
Lord's Day: ‘Sunday’, OEDO.
Sweet: ‘Dearly loved or prized, precious; beloved, dear’, OEDO.
Sweet: ‘Dearly loved or prized, precious; beloved, dear’, OEDO.

Salvation: 'The saving of the soul; the deliverance from sin and its consequences, and admission to eternal bliss, wrought for man by the atonement of Christ', OEDO. On Protestantism and salvation, see Alec Ryrie, Being Protestant in Reformation Britain (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2013), chap. 2.
Divine: ‘Any ecclesiastic, clergyman, or priest’, OEDO.

Providence: ‘The foreknowing and protective care of God (or nature, etc.); divine direction, control, or guidance’, OEDO. On providence in early modern England see Alexandra Walsham, Providence in Early Modern England (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 1999).
Approbation: ‘The action of expressing oneself pleased or satisfied with anything; or the mere feeling of such satisfaction; approval expressed or entertained’, OEDO.
Living: ‘A position as a vicar, rector, or other church official, conferring property or income or both; a benefice’, OEDO.
Guardian: ‘A person who has, or is by law entitled to, the custody of the person or property (or both) of an infant or other person legally incapable of managing his or her own affairs’, OEDO.
Living: ‘A position as a vicar, rector, or other church official, conferring property or income or both; a benefice’, OEDO.
Living: ‘A position as a vicar, rector, or other church official, conferring property or income or both; a benefice’, OEDO.
Temporal: ‘Secular as opposed to sacred’, OEDO.
Equity: ‘What is fair and right’, OEDO.
Truckle: 'To take a subordinate or inferior position; to be subservient', OEDO.
Living: ‘A position as a vicar, rector, or other church official, conferring property or income or both; a benefice’, OEDO.
Guardian: ‘A person who has, or is by law entitled to, the custody of the person or property (or both) of an infant or other person legally incapable of managing his or her own affairs’, OEDO.
Living: ‘A position as a vicar, rector, or other church official, conferring property or income or both; a benefice’, OEDO.
Prate: ‘To talk or chatter; to speak foolishly, boastfully, or at great length, esp. to little purpose; to prattle’, OEDO.
Popish: ‘Of or relating to Roman Catholicism or the Roman Catholic Church. Chiefly derogatory’, OEDO.
Alley: ‘A passage between the rows of pews or seats in a church; esp. such a passage running down the centre of the nave’, OEDO.
Hackle: ‘A cloak, a mantle, an outer garment’, OEDO.
Hiss: ‘To drive or send away with or by means of hissing’, OEDO.
Cure: ‘A parish or other sphere of spiritual ministration’, OEDO.
Stickler: ‘A person who stirs up strife or unrest; a meddler, a busybody’, OEDO.

Presbyterians: ‘Members of a church governed by elders or presbyters and minister in a hierarchy of representative courts. Their doctrine is fundamentally Calvinistic. The Church of Scotland became presbyterian after the Reformation’, Dictionary of Christianity, ed. J. C. Cooper (Abingdon: Routledge, 2013), 219-20. On presbyterianism in the seventeenth century, see Chad van Dixhoorn, ‘The Seventeenth Century and the Westminster Assembly’, in The Oxford Handbook of Presbyterianism, ed. Gary Scott Smith and P. C. Kemeny (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2019), 29-49.
Stamp: ‘Character, kind; fashion, make; cast, type’, OEDO.
Living: ‘A position as a vicar, rector, or other church official, conferring property or income or both; a benefice’, OEDO.
Living: ‘A position as a vicar, rector, or other church official, conferring property or income or both; a benefice’, OEDO.
Living: ‘A position as a vicar, rector, or other church official, conferring property or income or both; a benefice’, OEDO.
Delinquent: ‘An opponent of the Parliamentary party in 17th-cent. England; spec. a provider of financial or military aid, or other service, to the Royalist cause during the English Civil War’, OEDO.

Presbyterians: ‘Members of a church governed by elders or presbyters and minister in a hierarchy of representative courts. Their doctrine is fundamentally Calvinistic. The Church of Scotland became presbyterian after the Reformation’, Dictionary of Christianity, ed. J. C. Cooper (Abingdon: Routledge, 2013), 219-20. Kemeny (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2019), 29-49.
False quarter: ‘Defective, not firm or solid’, OEDO.
Living: ‘A position as a vicar, rector, or other church official, conferring property or income or both; a benefice’, OEDO.
Clew: ‘Used in reference to the thread of life, which the Fates are represented as spinning’, OEDO.
Bottom: ‘To serve as a basis or foundation for; to provide a basis or foundation for, establish firmly’, OEDO.
Poor: ‘To be pitied; unfortunate, wretched, hapless’, OEDO.
Imbrue:’ ‘To stain, dye (one's hand, sword, etc.) in or with (blood, slaughter, etc.)’, OEDO.
Bloody-guilty: 'Responsible for bloodshed or killing; characterized by blood guilt', OEDO.
Delinquent: ‘A provider of financial or military aid, or other service, to the Royalist cause during the English Civil War’, OEDO.
Living: ‘A position as a vicar, rector, or other church official, conferring property or income or both; a benefice’, OEDO.
Sequestration: 'Seizure of the possessions of a subject by the state', OEDO.
Popery: ‘The doctrines, practices, and ceremony associated with the Pope or the Roman Catholic Church; papal power or domination; Roman Catholicism’, OEDO.
Heathenism: ‘Heathen beliefs or practices, esp. regarded as primitive or uncivilized’, OEDO.
Trooper: ‘A soldier in a troop of cavalry; a horse soldier’, OEDO.

Oath: ‘A solemn or formal declaration invoking God (or a god, or other object of reverence) as witness to the truth of a statement’, OEDO. On oaths and oath-taking in early modern England see John Spurr, 'A Profane History of Early Modern Oaths', Transactions of the Royal Historical Society 11 (2001): 37–63.
Sequestration: ‘Seizure of the possessions of a subject by the state’, OEDO.

Quality: ‘A personal attribute, a trait, a feature of a person's character’, OEDO.

Perquisite: ‘An acquired piece of property’, OEDO.

Backward: ‘Reluctant, averse, unwilling, loath, chary’, OEDO.

Strait: ‘A dilemma; a difficulty of choice’, OEDO.

The Church of Scotland became presbyterian after the Reformation’, Dictionary of Christianity, ed. J. C. Cooper (Abingdon: Routledge, 2013), 219-20. Posterity: 'The descendants collectively of any person', OEDO.
Country: ‘The land of a person's birth … in the narrower one of the particular district to which a person belongs’, OEDO.
Chiefest: ‘At the head or top in importance; most important, influential’, OEDO.
Depute: ‘To appoint, assign, ordain (a person or thing) to or for a particular office, purpose, or function’, OEDO.

Jointure: ‘A sole estate limited to the wife, being a competent livelihood of freehold for the wife of lands and tenements, to take effect upon the death of the husband for the life of the wife at least’, OEDO. See Amy Louise Erickson, Women and Property in Early Modern England (London: Routledge, 1995), 25-6; 119-22.
Portion: ‘The part or share of an estate given or passing by law to an heir or other beneficiary, or to be distributed to an heir in the settlement of the estate’, OEDO.
Table: ‘Provision of food for meals; board’, OEDO.
Country: ‘An area of land of defined extent characterized by its human occupants or boundaries; a district or administrative region, typically one smaller than a nation or state’, OEDO.

Providence: ‘The foreknowing and protective care of God (or nature, etc.); divine direction, control, or guidance’, OEDO. On providence in early modern England see Alexandra Walsham, Providence in Early Modern England (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 1999).

Portion: ‘The part or share of an estate given or passing by law to an heir or other beneficiary, or to be distributed to an heir in the settlement of the estate’, OEDO. See Amy Louise Erickson, 'Coverture and Capitalism', History Workshop Journal, no. 59 (2005): 1–16.

Videlicet: 'That is to say', OEDO.
Covenant: ‘To enter into a covenant or formal agreement; to agree formally or solemnly; to contract’, OEDO.

Entail: ‘The settlement of the succession of a landed estate, so that it cannot be bequeathed at pleasure by any one possessor; the rule of descent settled for any estate; the fixed or prescribed line of devolution’, OEDO.

Marriage settlement: ‘A legal arrangement which secures certain property for an intended wife and sometimes also for any children of an intended marriage; a deed by which such an arrangement is effected; (occasionally) property settled in such an arrangement’, OEDO.

Entail: ‘The settlement of the succession of a landed estate, so that it cannot be bequeathed at pleasure by any one possessor; the rule of descent settled for any estate; the fixed or prescribed line of devolution’, OEDO.
Portion: ‘The part or share of an estate given or passing by law to an heir or other beneficiary, or to be distributed to an heir in the settlement of the estate’, OEDO.
Anarchy: ‘A state of political or social disorder resulting from the absence or disregard of government or the rule of law’, OEDO.
Sweet: ‘Dearly loved or prized, precious; beloved, dear’, OEDO.
Settlement: 'The act of settling property upon a person or persons; the particular terms of such an arrangement; the deed or instrument by which it is effected’, OEDO.
Deed of settlement: ‘The deed by which the settling property upon a person or persons is effected’, OEDO.

Entail: ‘The settlement of the succession of a landed estate, so that it cannot be bequeathed at pleasure by any one possessor; the rule of descent settled for any estate; the fixed or prescribed line of devolution’, OEDO.
Portion: ‘The part or share of an estate given or passing by law to an heir or other beneficiary, or to be distributed to an heir in the settlement of the estate’, OEDO.

Bond: ‘A deed, by which A (known as the obligor) binds himself or herself, his or her heirs, executors, or assigns to pay a certain sum of money to B (known as the obligee), or his or her heirs, etc.’, OEDO.
Portion: ‘The part or share of an estate given or passing by law to an heir or other beneficiary, or to be distributed to an heir in the settlement of the estate’, OEDO.
Article: ‘Each of the distinct heads or points of an agreement or treaty. Chiefly in plural: a set of these points comprising a formal agreement (frequently with of)’, OEDO.
Temporal: ‘Secular as opposed to sacred’, OEDO.
Bitter: ‘Having a harmful or destructive effect; cruel’, OEDO.

Salvation: ‘The saving of the soul; the deliverance from sin and its consequences, and admission to eternal bliss, wrought for man by the atonement of Christ’, OEDO. See Amy Louise Erickson, Women and Property in Early Modern England (London: Routledge, 1995), 25-6, 119-22.

Jointure: ‘A sole estate limited to the wife, being a competent livelihood of freehold for the wife of lands and tenements, to take effect upon the death of the husband for the life of the wife at least’, OEDO. See Amy Louise Erickson, Women and Property in Early Modern England (London: Routledge, 1995), 25-6, 119-22.
Liberty: ‘Unrestricted use of or access’, OEDO.

Without impeachment of waste: ‘When a tenant for life holds the land without impeachment of waste, he is of course dispunishable for waste whether willful or otherwise. But still this right must not be wantonly abused so as to destroy the estate, and he will be enjoined from committing malicious waste. The effect of the insertion of this clause in a lease for life is to give the tenant the right to cut timber on the estate, without making himself thereby liable to an action for waste’. ‘Without Impeachment of Waste’, TheLaw.com Dictionary, https://dictionary.thelaw.com/without-impeachment-of-waste/.

Jointure: ‘A sole estate limited to the wife, being a competent livelihood of freehold for the wife of lands and tenements, to take effect upon the death of the husband for the life of the wife at least’, OEDO. See Amy Louise Erickson, Women and Property in Early Modern England (London: Routledge, 1995), 25-6, 119-22.
Firebote: ‘Firewood, esp. that which a tenant is entitled to take from a landlord's estate for fuel; (hence) the right or privilege of a tenant to take such wood’, OEDO.

Housebote: ‘The right or privilege of a tenant to take wood from a landlord's estate for the upkeep of a house; (also) the rent paid for this privilege; (the clearing or taking of) wood for this purpose’, OEDO.

Hedgebote (or Haybote): ‘Wood or thorns for the repair of fences; the right of the tenant or commoner to take such material from the landlord's estate, or the common. By legal writers also called hedgebote’, OEDO.

Jointure: ‘A sole estate limited to the wife, being a competent livelihood of freehold for the wife of lands and tenements, to take effect upon the death of the husband for the life of the wife at least’, OEDO. See Amy Louise Erickson, Women and Property in Early Modern England (London: Routledge, 1995), 25-6, 119-22.
Portion: ‘The part or share of an estate given or passing by law to an heir or other beneficiary, or to be distributed to an heir in the settlement of the estate’, OEDO.
Condescension: ‘Concession’, OEDO.
Equity: ‘The quality of being equal or fair’, OEDO.

Entail: ‘The settlement of the succession of a landed estate, so that it cannot be bequeathed at pleasure by any one possessor; the rule of descent settled for any estate; the fixed or prescribed line of devolution’, OEDO.
Wholesome: ‘Physically or morally healthy; virtuous’, OEDO.
Cordial: ‘Heartfelt, hearty; sincere, genuine; thoroughly committed to a course of action or a cause’, OEDO.
Portion: ‘The part or share of an estate given or passing by law to an heir or other beneficiary, or to be distributed to an heir in the settlement of the estate’, OEDO.
Advise: ‘To take counsel or confer together, to make joint deliberation’, OEDO.
Portion: ‘The part or share of an estate given or passing by law to an heir or other beneficiary, or to be distributed to an heir in the settlement of the estate’, OEDO.
Keep up: ‘To keep secret or undivulged’, OEDO.
Close: ‘To conclude, bring to a close or end; to finish, complete’, OEDO.

Bitter: ‘Expressing intense grief, misery, or affliction of spirit’, OEDO.

Delicate: ‘Having a weak or fragile constitution, not strong or robust; highly susceptible or vulnerable to injury, sickness, or disease; (of a person's constitution) not strong or robust’, OEDO.
Pass a fine: ‘A means of conveyance in cases where the ordinary means were unavailable or less effective’, OEDO.

Execute: ‘To go through the formalities necessary to the validity of (a legal act, e.g. a bequest, agreement, mortgage, etc.). Hence, to complete and give validity to (the instrument by which such act is effected) by performing what the law requires to be done, as by signing, sealing, etc’, OEDO.

Videlicet: 'That is to say', OEDO.
Grief: ‘Mental pain, distress, or sorrow’, OEDO.
Assignment: ‘Appointment to office, nomination, designation; setting apart for a purpose’, OEDO.
Bounty: ‘Goodness shown in giving, gracious liberality, munificence’, OEDO.
Posterity: ‘The descendants collectively of any person (or, in extended use, any living thing); all who are descended from a common ancestor’, OEDO.
Grief: ‘Hurt, harm, mischief or injury done or caused by another’, ‘Mental pain, distress, or sorrow’,OEDO.

Rail: ‘To utter abusive language; to complain persistently, to rant’, OEDO.

Base: ‘Morally low; despicable, ignoble; reprehensibly cowardly, craven; selfish, mean’, OEDO.
Smart: ‘To feel sharp pain or distress (in later use esp. with a stinging pain); to suffer acutely or severely’, OEDO.

Oath: ‘A solemn or formal declaration invoking God (or a god, or other object of reverence) as witness to the truth of a statement’, OEDO. On oaths and oath-taking in early modern England see John Spurr, 'A Profane History of Early Modern Oaths', Transactions of the Royal Historical Society 11 (2001): 37–63.

Presbyterians: ‘Members of a church governed by elders or presbyters and minister in a hierarchy of representative courts. Their doctrine is fundamentally Calvinistic. The Church of Scotland became presbyterian after the Reformation’, Dictionary of Christianity, ed. J. C. Cooper (Abingdon: Routledge, 2013), 219-20. On presbyterianism in the seventeenth century, see Chad van Dixhoorn, ‘The Seventeenth Century and the Westminster Assembly’, in The Oxford Handbook of Presbyterianism, ed. Gary Scott Smith and P. C. Kemeny (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2019), 29-49.

Settlement: ‘The act of settling property upon a person or persons; the particular terms of such an arrangement; the deed or instrument by which it is effected’, OEDO.
Chamber: ‘A room or suite of rooms in a house, typically one allotted to the use of a particular person, a private room’, OEDO.
Sweet: ‘Dearly loved or prized, precious; beloved, dear’, OEDO.
Looseness: ‘Laxity (of the bowels), esp. as a morbid symptom’, OEDO.
Sweet: ‘Dearly loved or prized, precious; beloved, dear’, OEDO.
Goodly: ‘Of good or pleasing appearance; handsome, beautiful, good-looking; comely, fair’, OEDO.
Cancer: ‘Any of various types of non-healing sore or ulcer', OEDO.
Repose: ‘The state of being quietly inactive or relaxed, or of being free from care, anxiety, or other disturbances; ease, serenity’, OEDO.
Chamber: ‘A room or suite of rooms in a house, typically one allotted to the use of a particular person, a private room’, OEDO.
Chamber: ‘A room or suite of rooms in a house, typically one allotted to the use of a particular person, a private room’, OEDO.
Bold: ‘Audacious, presumptuous, too forward’, OEDO.
Article: ‘Each of the distinct heads or points of an agreement or treaty. Chiefly in plural: a set of these points comprising a formal agreement (frequently with of)’, OEDO.
Chamber: ‘A room or suite of rooms in a house, typically one allotted to the use of a particular person, a private room’, OEDO.
Forgery: ‘Deception, lying; a fraudulent artifice, a deceit’, OEDO.
Posterity: ‘The descendants collectively of any person (or, in extended use, any living thing); all who are descended from a common ancestor’, OEDO.
Tincture: ‘A trace; a smattering’, OEDO.
Calumny: ‘A false charge or imputation, intended to damage another's reputation; a slanderous report’, OEDO.
Traduce: ‘To defame, malign, vilify, slander’, OEDO.

Providence: ‘The foreknowing and protective care of God (or nature, etc.); divine direction, control, or guidance’, OEDO. On providence in early modern England see Alexandra Walsham, Providence in Early Modern England (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 1999).
Purloin: ‘To steal’, OEDO.
Occasion: ‘A pretext; an excuse’, OEDO.

Deportment: ‘Manner of conducting oneself; conduct (of life); behaviour’, OEDO.

Sift: ‘To subject (one) to close questioning’, OEDO.
Flooding: ‘Fullness, superabundance’, OEDO.
Grief: ‘Hurt, harm, mischief or injury done or caused by another’, OEDO.

Causelessly: ‘In a causeless way; without cause or reason’, OEDO.
Palsy: ‘Paralysis or paresis (weakness) of all or part of the body, sometimes with tremor’, OEDO.
Clyster: ‘A medicine injected into the rectum, to empty or cleanse the bowels, to afford nutrition, etc.; an injection, enema; sometimes, a suppository’, OEDO.
Posterity: ‘The descendants collectively of any person (or, in extended use, any living thing); all who are descended from a common ancestor’, OEDO.
Palsy: ‘Paralysis or paresis (weakness) of all or part of the body, sometimes with tremor; an instance of this’, OEDO.
Convulsion: ‘An involuntary contraction, stiffening, or ‘drawing up’ of a muscle, limb, etc.’, OEDO.
Choir: ‘That part of a church appropriated to the singers’, OEDO.
Father: ‘A male ancestor more remote than a parent; a forefather’, OEDO.
